Definition: In this task, you will receive a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to divide the comment into two classes: insult and non-insult. Insulting is any language or action that is disrespectful or contemptuous.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: I guess when you're clueless you stick your head into every hole.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Hillary Clinton was not my girlfriend.

I did not have sexual relations with that woman.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be obscene but not insult.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: She is weak and useless, time to run her off
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is disrespectful.

Comment: I used to work for a bank till the late 1980s. It was difficult to make ends meet, with all the deductions from my salary. So I quit my job, and started my own business, with capital I got from a mortgage loan on my house. It became even more difficult financially at first, as in most start-ups. However, I made a go of it for 10 years. I actually made less than I did in my old job, but because my wife and I worked together, we took dividends from the business, which minimized our taxes, and avoided all the usual payroll deductions. That was the only way we survived.

While doing that, I met hundreds of other people in similar situations. They were leading a way of life that no one in a government or unionized job will understand. So when Trudeau/Morneau talk about "equalizing" them with salaried people by taxing them more, they are really assaulting a whole way of life, which millions of Canadians lead. That's what has stressed out so many people, even without looking at specifics.

Comment: Motley, and good recovery from you.  Not many folks here like to admit they were ever wrong.  But this was an easy mistake to  make , for when we Americans hear the words "Spanish war" we immediately think of that 1898  Spanish-American War  with Teddy's Rough Riders and "Rem ember the Maine.!"
But the actual Spanish Civil War is virtually unknown here--I remember taking an Army entrance exam back in 1958 being asked about belonging to a number of suspicious organizations, including the Abraham Lincoln   Brigade, which sparked my curiousity  as I'd never heard of it.

A Spanish Civil War story--  back around 1968 I heard a presentation by an older Spanish sociologist.  Afterwards I asked him if he thought Spain would have another Civil War.  I'll never forget his answer--he shook his head and said:
"Civil War is so horrible, so terrible, that once a nation has fought one, they will never want to fight another one."
    And fortunately, Spain  freed itself from Fascism without a war.

Comment: Describing as 'settlor' any human who arrived in the past 500 years is a bit arbitrary.  
Humans have been around for about 200,000 years, and the last ice age was about 12,000 years ago.  
Indigenous means native, occurring naturally.  The word does not distinguish between arriving 500 years ago and arriving 15,000 years ago within a 200,000 year time frame.  The word you are looking for to describe earlier arrivals is aboriginal.

Comment: The real problem is that its a blanket statement saying that ALL trans people are to be excluded from serving in the military in ANY capacity.  What about the trans person who has been post-op for several years and no longer requires any follow-up procedures or anything like that. We arnt even just talking about combat troops.  What about a skilled translator?  Or someone who is very good at doing cyber intelligence.  We are saying to these people, regardless of what skills you have that might help the country - we dont want your services.

Comment: AJ, you really do not know what you are talking about. I have lived off-grid on solar for 15 years and have been installing solar systems for ten years. Anyone who knows even a little bit knows that solar energy is dramatically reduced by cloud. When a cold front comes over your energy intake can be reduced by 90% compared to what you get on a sunny day. If the the cloud is thinner then the reduction is more like 75%. 

This is why you need 5 days backup. This is like Grade 1 of understanding solar.

Anyway, your level of ignorance means that in effect you are now trolling these comments. You state things vehemently as truth when you actually don't understand. Comment: Apply that same reasoning to any civil law --for example, the speed limit on residential streets -- and you'll see it doesn't work.   I can't argue that I have the right to drive 100 mph because my conscience tells me I can.

One can argue that a  law is an imposition of unfair arbitrary presumptions, and that every individual is a sovereign citizen who is beholden to none of societies laws.    There is actually a sovereign citizen movement -- check out the youtube videos.   But it's not a legal philosophy that is recognized as legitimate by any U.S. judge.   Why?   Because it's ultimately a legal philosophy based on the notion that laws and democracy are illegitimate abuses of power against the individual.

One can certainly argue that a society should legalize abortion for everyone, but in making that argument, you can't at the same time argue that those who disagree on abortion don't have the right to make their argument.    Isn't that basically what you're doing here?

Comment: Charles is on the right track here. We need to get our own house in order before taking on oil tax system reform for the 4th time in 4 years. It seems we are close to agreeing on a sustainable rate of draw from the PF Earnings at a rate of 4-5% per annum of  the principal value of the Fund. A low income tax in conjunction with the end of the Dividend (for the foreseeable future) is the grand bargain in sight. It will be impossible to get one without the other. Maintaining a Dividend would be an unconstitutional use of income derived from a broad based tax from both a political and constitutional perspective. A lawsuit would be filed before the ink is dry if the Legislature tries it. Maintaining a Dividend without an income tax (as the R's seem to be proposing) is fiscally irresponsible. Seaton's Dividend/Tax Credit proposal is even more unconstitutional. The only responsible solution is to end the Dividend and keep that $0.7-1.4 billion/year in the PF earning income into the future.

Comment: 1.  If one group of of property owners get to pay less tax, then other groups of property owners will get to pay more.

2.  Property taxes are based on the value of your property, which was seen historically as a proxy for your wealth -- long before anyone thought of taxing incomes.  The more wealthy you were, the more property you were likely to own. 

3.  The complaining businesses are paying more tax because their properties are becoming more valuable -- often because of market forces beyond their control.  They will reap this unearned extra value when they sell.  

4.  The only just way to lower their tax bills is to have a formula to defer part of the tax, to be paid, with reasonably accrued annual interest, on the sale of the property.  When the vendors capture the increase in property value, the city captures the deferred taxes.

5.  It would be abusive for the property owners to avoid the tax increase but receive the property value increase,
.

Comment: I'm reminded of that landmark paper: _The Basic Laws of Human Stupidity_ by Carlo M. Cipolla, Former Professor of Economics at University UC Berkeley.

-First Law: Always and inevitably everyone underestimates the number of stupid individuals in circulation.
-Second Law: The probability that a certain person be stupid is independent of any other characteristic of that person.
-Third (and Golden) Law: A stupid person is a person who causes losses to another person or to a group of persons while himself deriving no gain and even possibly incurring losses.
-Fourth Law: Non-stupid people always underestimate the damaging power of stupid individuals. In particular non-stupid people constantly forget that at -all times and places and under any circumstances to deal and/or associate with stupid people always turns out to be a costly mistake.
-Fifth Law: A stupid person is the most dangerous type of person.
-Corollary to the 5th Law: A stupid person is more dangerous than a bandit.

Paul

Comment: Actually it is in FACT both the Storm Surge and Inland Flooding converging because the storm is essentially stuck in place

The main reason it's stuck is because the Jet Stream is all out of whack again and there is a big bow in the western half of the continent and a big dip in the eastern part. The reason the Jet Stream is all out of whack again is because of record ice melt in the Arctic which weakens the Jet Stream and causes it to dip and bow

Since we cannot determine what the Jet Stream looked like historically there was no way to predict it's affects but many. myself included suspected it would have a major effect on hurricanes in the right scenarios and this event is proving that suspicion to be true

Comment: At a flat $60k, online tax bracket estimators for federal and Oregon taxes combined (with no deductions at all, which is unlikely) result in a little over $17k in taxes, leaving you with a net of $43k.

Your 50/30/20 breakdown results in $1,790 for necessities.

$1,075-ish can go towards "financial obligations."

$716 can go towards "personal choices," meaning your "personal choices" budget is about $24/day.

A truly wonderful, self-reflective follow up article would be a daily "personal choices" diary of how this author (and maybe some volunteer friends) spend their money.  Is she or the average Portlander being responsible in only spending 20% of their net income on "personal choices," and thus justified in complaining about the rest of the equation and state of affairs in Portland proper? Comment: I'm not going to comment, just tell a true story. Several years ago the mice moved in. They were everywhere. In the pantry, the sink, in the bed, in the closets, in the walls, in the ceiling. I lay my head on my pillow and it moved, there were mice under it. I took pans from the cabinet and there were mouse droppings in them. The knife and fork drawer had mice running all over in it. Mice ran across our feet and our faces at night. The floor was crunchy when we walked. I put poison all over and they carried it and hid it in our bed. Then squirrels moved in. They ate our clothes, our furniture and chewed into the cannisters of food. Big poop everywhere! I took sheets out of the washer and a dead squirrel fell out. Then some stray cats moved in under the store across the street. Within a week all the mice and squirrels had moved on. The entire town treasured those cats. We didn't live in shacks, that is a $300,000 7 bedroom house. It can happen to you. I will never harm an outdoor cat.

Comment: " 'Shop' teachers are like gym teachers; they are basically babysitters."

What a silly, ill-informed comment. 
The number one responsibility of every teacher is the safety of other people's children. I don't have stats to prove it but I'd guess that the leading places for injury are the playground, the gym and shops (most elementary schools no longer have a shop/'industrial arts' program). 

Fatalities and serious injuries are relatively rare but that has not stopped the ongoing curtailment of activities that could result in injury such as gymnastics, wrestling, high jump & shotput, power tools, monkey bars & swings, etc.

Kids are the losers when these activities are eliminated. These activities can occur in relative safety but only under the close supervision of a competent, vigilant teacher. 
A baby-sitter won't cut it.

Comment: What most city bureaucrats refuse to acknowledge and understand is the cost of delays.  In the private investment world, 3 months is a long time.

I used to participate as a business volunteer in another community that met with business leaders that were contemplating locating a new facility in our community.  One of the primary questions of us was always how long will it take to get thru the bureaucracy so we can break ground.   We lost businesses because of that factor when other communities offered expedited permitting and cooperation.

It is a big deal for private investors due to the time value of money.  A public employee who is used to sitting on their butts with almost no consequence for delays in work has a hard time understanding why this is such a big deal to potential employers and other investors.

Perhaps all planners, permit approvers, etc. should be required to take financial coursework, and attend workshops with entrepreneurs to listen to investment priorities?

Comment: There is never a good time to propose changes to tax laws. Maybe the announcement could have timed it better but I doubt it. The problem is that the changes are being sensationalized by Tories and financial adviser con men, not to mention the media that is always looking for stories that catch eyeballs. 

Most of the commentary I see on this topic involves narrow interpretations of the consequences that do not take into account all the tax options small businesses have. They will pay more tax but not as much as is claimed.

For example, income sprinkling can still happen. The only change is that one's relatives must actually be on the payroll, their incomes subject to standard deductions and taxes.

Small businesses will have to adjust their accounting practices. Once they do it will be business as usual. They may even benefit insofar as they will not need as much in the way of accounting services.

Life will go on.

Comment: Thomas Pease mischaracterizes my “one-size-fits-all approach” for bears in Anchorage neighborhoods. I’ve never believed there’s a single solution. Since the early 1990s, long before bear carts were available in Anchorage, I’ve advocated keeping garbage in garages and other methods. And I’ve talked to hundreds of people who refused to keep their garbage in a garage or wait until the morning of pickup to carry plastic bags to the curb. Few listened at first, but I believe my constant nagging for two decades, often in the newspaper, helped raise consciousness in Anchorage and other communities.

During those years I tried working cooperatively. I created the Anchorage Bear Committee, for instance. However, I admit I'm better at playing "bad cop" than "good cop." That's because 2 decades taught me that before any progress can be made, one sometimes has to toss a grenade down the stairs.

Trump did not have his feet put to fire to put details on his political thinking (I frankly don't think he has any).  He was not forced to do any thinking on serious and complicated issues.  It was simply a marketing campaign based upon a personality cult.  The US media collectively wet the bed, and a charlatan will now occupy the oval office.

If O'Leary runs, scrutinize him, and make him demonstrate that he has real substance.  Moreover, let's see if he treats the electorate and his opponents with the decorum and respect that the political process deserves.

Comment: OS, take it easy. What constitutes an education is totally subjective; I can't really prove my claims other than the links I provided you showing how Oregon's schools ranks near or at the bottom nationally. But my assessment had nothing to do with low test scores or the lowest (behind Puerto Rico?) graduation rates. It was a critique of WHAT 4J teaches. I could delve into Postmodernism, Deconstruction, and all of the other trendy far-left philosophical and educational movements that have denuded education from K-12 to our universities. But I won't. 

East Coast prep schools assign Plato and Thucydides, a Southern school might assign the kids to memorize the Constitution and in Eugene we teach them to garden. I know all about the AP and IHS programs at South. The U of O is an inferior institution. I wouldn't send my kids there if it were free. Those are my opinions and I would like to open people's minds to their truthfulness, but I'm not suggesting anyone take my word for anything.

Labor laws preventing age discrimination are virtually impossible to enforce, considering you are fighting basic competitive market theory.

Comment: Goatie made reference to the intangibles related to the work of Babcock.  But it goes beyond that.  Shanahan did more than find good leaders that made good calls on the draft as noted above.  He started a complete re-build initially through a scorched earth process of firing scouts, coaches, and management staff.  He did this in the context of a different culture that he articulated.  The people he deleted from the organization did not fit the culture he sought.  And the people he brought in were aligned with that culture that was reinforced on a continual basis through action.  This is what it takes to build a winning franchise on a consistent basis.

It is not a sure fire process.  He got lucky getting the #1 pick (Matthews), he trusted the system so that Hunter emerged with the winning voice to pick Marner (many thought he was too small), etc.

Even if Matthews did not come to town, the process was in place for potential success.  Matthews accelerated the results, for now.

Comment: Most people like their plans because most people do not buy individual policies on the exchanges-- less than 20% of Americans buy individual Obamacare policies on the exchanges. Half of Americans get their policies from where they work and they and their employer are happy with that. They get group discounts from policies paid for by their employer (who likes providing this benefit because they get a tax credit for it). Employees also do not need to include the employer's payment of a share of the premium in taxable income because of a federal excemption for it. The group plans cover larger pools and are standardized across state lines so insurance companies like them. Republicans have not changed this so far (the danger is that they cut the employer credit and the employee exemption in order to fund tax cuts in the tax reform bill and in the Obamacare repeal. Listen to the insurers who have good ideas on fixing the individual plans and exchanges.

Comment: Honoring my oath to support and defend the Constitution of the United State and honoring my professional and personal beliefs and integrity, I can no longer serve as Acting Attorney General of the United States and, herewith, resign. "  Such an act would have, IMO, been far, far more effective than being "fired."  Principled resignations have great meaning and, importantly, the individual controls the discussion as the "moving party."  Being fired for insubordination puts one "on the defensive" and taints the message as an "excuse" for the insubordination, rather than a principled act.  

I think we both feel the order will be found "illegal", but I think we'll be seeing numerous "Presidential Executive Orders" which we and many others feel are illegal.  However, they are "legal" until a Court determines they are "illegal" and they may (and, likely will) be enforced until a Court issues an order blocking them pending a decision on their legality.  "we live in interesting times."  Gary

Comment: Street signs and town names are not will keep a language alive. It is parents who keep it alive. Comment: VISA and MasterCard are dual monopolies

I have long said that VISA and MasterCard are oligopolies from the point of view of consumers who need one or the other. But they are clear monopolies from the point of view of businesses who are virtually forced to accept both of these cards at whatever fee they charge.

Reward cards are a sort of kick-back scheme.

There was a time when governments would regulate fees on monopolies. But that often led to bloat as well. 

It is a very simple matter for government to mandate say a 1% maximum fee. The credit card companies would not go away because of it.

It is also outrageous that these monopolies can forbid retailers from telling customers that they prefer cash or debit card.

Disclosure: I own shares in VISA and American Express.  I am not blind to their outrageous fees. VISA is monopolicious for investors. VISA and MasterCard claim that they operate in a highly competitive business. That claim is completely laughable.

Comment: Market Failure: Economic Rent Extraction and Information Asymmetry in Canadian Housing Market

Economic Rent Extraction
Canadian tax payers are making this country a great place to live, while foreign investors are extracting economic rent from Canada's high living standards, both in the form of collecting real rent from Canadian residents (tax payers) and gaining from the sales and taking money out of the country after flipping/selling the properties back to Canadian residents (tax payers) at a much higher price!

Information Asymmetry
The "blind" biding for house purchase is where there is information asymmetry between sellers and buyers and is a free market failure.  It requires government intervention.   If there is bidding, it should be open auction.  When there are three offers on a house listed for $800K;  and the offers are $800K, $850K and $1100K, it is a clear indication of free market failure and exploitation of blind bidding by the real estate agents.

Comment: I like raccoons, too.  Just a couple of weeks ago, I was watching the Rockies game when my cat started making strange catterwalling sounds and went to the sliding glass door that leads to a porch.  I got up to see what was going on, thinking it was another cat, but no, my cat was rubbing noses through the glass with a raccoon!  I walked right up to the door and the 'coon just looked at me.  I'm sure if I'd opened the door, he would have walked right in.  No fear at all.  He hung around about an hour, then climbed a trellis to the top of the fence and scampered off after finding no dog food in the yard.

A couple of years ago, I heard a commotion on the deck.  I flipped on the light, and a really big, fat raccoon waddled off.  I'd stored some bird seed in a cabinet on the deck, and he'd managed to open the cabinet door to get into it.   I have no idea how he managed climb the fence, as fat as he was.  

Had a duck hang around about 4 hours earlier this summer.

Comment: "The fact is, we reached the threshold of 400 and can't do much except prepare for the worst" 
There is no data or observations to back up that statement.
"Carbon taxes aren't going to reverse the 400 which likely will hit 500 by the end of this decade." 
That's just ridiculous. Since its inception in about 1958 to the present ,the average increase is about 1.5ppm per year
see: scripps.ucsd.edu/programs/keelingcurve
Now compare the annual increases in CO2 emissions from fossil fuels over the same time period. We go from about 9000mmt to 3200mmt. A increase by a factor of about 3.5 times. The rate of increase on the keeling graph hardly moves, but we are told that we are driving the growing atmosphere CO2 rate.
see: Historical Global CO2 Emissions @ c2es.org/facts-figures

Comment: Everyone that is all for shipping Alberta crude/tar sand's oil through the Gulf Islands and the Salish Sea, I suggest that you come here and walk the beaches.  Come down to any of the many spots where it is possible to view the Orcas swimming past in their pods.  The river otter, seals and sea lions, and the multitude of birds that use this area as a flyway and resting area, are all at risk if there is an oil spill, are you ready to exchange this for an oil soaked coast?  

We humans and fauna that do live here certainly don't want to exchange our home for an equivalent of the Tar Sands, an industrial waste land.  Does that make us selfish?  I don't think so, I am ready to share this area, but not to the point where I agree to it's destruction, nor do I think you would agree to your town, neighbourhood be fouled with oil.  

Claiming that an area of the country should agree to allow its environment be befouled for the benefit of the rest of the country seems grossly unfair.

Comment: I like my work.  I write, I work mostly from home with periodic incursions into a variety of different offices and so forth.  I feel quasi free, relatively well remunerated and so forth.  Since I HAVE to work to live, I'm really lucky that it's worked out this way.  But I would say most people aren't so lucky.  They have to work too  - men and women both - but are trapped on a treadmill of rushing to work, which is becoming an ever more physically uninviting prospect (as firms tinker with a variety of ghastly 'open-office' environments), and then rushing home to deal with kids, meals and household chores.  

Historically - and it may take more than a few generations to change this - men linked their sense of self worth to their work.  Many women still don't do that.  And quite frankly, if they can get out of working for an employer (which is often not the same as doing something meaningful),  good for them.

Comment: I’m grateful to the WHIDBEY NEWS-TIMES providing coverage of my study, and would like to add some further commentary on the article and the comments. 

With respect to the article:
* I didn’t contact Mike Welding about the benefits of the Naval Air Station Whidbey Island (NASWI) because his information is, as he notes, “well known.”  It’s also obsolete.  The 2004 study he cites attributing 85% of Whidbey Island’s economy to the military was probably wrong in 2004, but it’s certainly wrong today.  The Navy is responsible for 20% of the jobs on the Island, not 85%.
* I also give these studies their due in my report.  What’s odd about these studies, however, is that they focused 100% on benefits of the NASWI and did no analysis whatsoever of the costs.  A cost-benefit analysis without the “cost” side of the picture misinforms public policy—and that was what my study sought to remedy.
-MORE-

Comment: Decision making tools that help overcome the trap of common sense have been around for more than 70 years.  At the outset of the second would war Britain used operations research to allocate its fighter plane resources in a counter intuitive way.  This set up the conditions for victory in the Battle of Britain and ultimately Britain's and our survival and victory in the war.  After the war, the US and Britain adapted these methods into systems engineering approaches that are at the core of the West's current supremacy in military technology.  Unfortunately, only limited use of these methods have penetrated industrial and government policy circles.  Culturally, managers and leaders just don't like to diminish discretionary decision making styles through greater reliance on modelling and analysis.
Intuitive decision making by those with authority seems to be central to the human condition.   Business schools and other leadership for a don't seemed to have made much of a dent in this bias

Comment: Asking emotional survivors who have just given testimony about their residential experiences about whether first nations should be audited (they already are) seems confrontational to me, as does the whole "silent majority vs. vocal minority" meme and the shots at political correctness.
Everyone goes through bad situations in their lives, and it's helpful to think of positives as you're going through the process of healing (as a minor example, a kind word from a staff member when you're in the hospital undergoing a painful or stressful procedure doesn't make the pain go away, but it helps you get through it) so I think it's important that the conversation around residential schools be broadened to encompass some of the positives, but the way Senator Beyak is going about this is ham-fisted, to say the least and will harden rather than broaden the survivor's outlook.

Comment: How Anyone Can Invest Their Way to Early Retirement:

-Don't go into debt for your education
-Get a job, preferably one in the public service with an indexed pension
-Once you have a well paying job, buy a reasonably priced house/condo - this is the only acceptable debt because real estate is an appreciating asset
-Buy a secondhand vehicle if you need one - don't finance it
-Take at least 10% of your paycheque and invest it prudently - then don't touch it
-As your income increases over the years, spend below your means
-Pay off your mortgage as soon as possible
-Put those savings into your RRSP

Voila, freedom 55 or perhaps earlier. Simple

Comment: The problem with this letter is that it is all one-sided. Women also bear responsibilities, of course, as far as generalities go. There is no easy slogan that possibly could apply to all situations, i.e. date rape, stranger assault, family abuse. Each situation must be weighed and decided upon its own facts. 
There are risks associated with certain lifestyles, certain behaviors, certain actions. To engage in them is to decide the risks are warranted. Certainly, that doesn't affect whether or not a crime is committed, but it does imply that the victim had some volition, some responsibility in the outcome. A woman that dresses in provocative clothing, goes to a bar at 3 a. m., gets drunk, and then walks to her car several blocks away (alone or with a stranger she has just met) isn't necessarily "asking" for anything. But sometimes, one can place oneself in situations where it is quite easy to get something that never  was asked for or wanted. 
Risky behaviors are that for a reason.

Comment: I appreciate the need for "balance" in an article but it is extremely misleading and dangerous to uninformed investors to equate the opinions of Mr. Hennigar with those of Mr. Mastracci.  Mr. Hennigar is a salesman and stands to benefit from selling you his funds - massively.  Mr. Mastracci would make nothing if someone were to purchase the ETFs he suggests.  Mr. Hennigar's funds charge a wealth-destroying 2.62% a year.  Mr. Mastracci's ETF's, which would provide you with equivalent diversification charge approximately 0.05% a year.  

To draw an analogy, Mr. Hennigar is arguing the earth is flat while Mr. Mastracci is arguing the earth is round.  An uninformed investor might be swayed by either argument, but one is clearly correct and the other is clearly incorrect.  

I would strongly suggest that before publishing this type of "balanced" article you back test the proposed portfolios over various time-frames.

Comment: If someone doesn't already own a home, I can understand the hand-wringing, but for an existing homeowner in Toronto, why is this a problem? The value of their biggest asset is going up. Would they prefer that it stagnate or decline? Of course not. I'd bet the number of existing homeowners in the GTA far exceeds the number of people looking for homes at any given time. Also note that as soon as a prospective buyer becomes a homeowner, their attitude immediately changes from wanting the government to help them get a better price, to wanting the value of their purchase to go up.

If the government interferes with the market, they will be on the wrong side of what the majority of the public want, and will suffer for it. Putting their thumb on the scale in favour of buyers, in a totally private transaction, is going to totally pee-off everyone else.

Comment: Traffic signals are not operated by "pressure switches" there is a copper wire loop embedded in the pavement that signals the vehicles metal/magnetic signature.  The "box" you see on the roadway is a series of cuts in the asphalt with the wire laid in it and covered with a protective sealant, and not a pressure pad.

That is why a bicycle or motorcycle will not set off a traffic signal, because if its low metal content, not its weight.

Comment: A false analogy is when the similarity in one respect of two concepts is taken as sufficient to establish that they are similar in another respect in which they are in fact dissimilar. 

It seems that you were under the impression that a false analogy is one in which the things being compared do not share the similarity. That would be a disanalogy.

If you were trying to show that this is a disanalogy, you would merely have to show how Zille saying things that offend people about infrastructure gains from colonialism is not similar to Americans saying things that may offend people about their ill-begotten gains from Nazi scientists during Operation Paperclip.

I'm not sure what one would call it when one focuses on the dissimilar aspects, which were not relevant to the analogy, like value judgements concerning the Space Race, and then claiming the analogy doesn't hold, despite acknowledging the similar aspects, upon which an analogy rests.

Comment: Nancy,
There are communities in Alaska that are 100% tribal members. Maybe you folks don't have them up there but we do down here. I am pretty sure there are villages up North where the majority are Tribal members. Tribes that have tribal court can prosecute tribal members for low level crimes. Non-Natives can elect to be tried in tribal court for a crime or in a state court. You might be surprised that many of the tribes in the lower 48 have laws almost identical to our state's law. They have to follow federal law, that means people have the same rights under the United States Constitution when it comes to being arrested or convicted for a crime.
As for child protection cases, they will follow ICWA as it is a federal law, regarding placement of children removed from their homes and follow it for adoptions.
If a Tribal member is arrested in Anchorage for a crime, they will still be prosecuted in state court. State laws have to be obeyed as do Federal laws.

Comment: Actually, they are first and foremost a phone company. Their roots are in true Telco; long-distance and local phone service. This has evolved into wireless phone service. GCI not only does NOT profit from their "exorbitantly priced cable packages"; GCI LOSES money on their cable TV service offerings. Believe me when I say - there is no money in cable TV anymore. Prices are not actually set by the cable company - they are set by the parent networks like Viacom -  who then sell their channel bundles to the cable companies. You are right in that the cable industry will collapse eventually.  You are also right about the shift in content consumption. If GCI offered truly unlimited service, why would anyone pay for a service package? I would just pay a small rental fee to leech off of my neighbor. Telco companies also have to make changes in order to keep up.

Comment: And this, ladies and gentlemen, is why the correct interpretation of the First Amendment should be "Freedom From Religion" not just "Freedom Of Religion".  The constitution guarantees equal time must be given for all religions, even those that you may disagree with or that have different tenets than yours.  You must either accept this, or decide that no religion can be given favoritism and thus protect yourself from being subjected to a religion that you might find offensive.

This is the plight of the atheist in today's society.  We are forced to endure your particular religion, whichever that may be, even though we don't agree with it.  This is not saying you aren't free to believe what you want to believe, just that you cannot thrust your belief onto others, because they may not believe the same thing.  In this case, it protects the believer just as much as it protects the non-believer, by guaranteeing that you don't have to be exposed to something you don't believe.

Comment: Charles, you failed to understand Hickel's revelation and what it really meant. Wally had been told by members of Congress and the President of the United States that Alaskans would not be permitted to own our mineral wealth. We could choose to hold it in common as a state, but under no circumstances would we be allowed to own our subsurface mineral resources as individuals. We therefore were required to write our constitution in a way that forever impoverished the people of Alaska at the benefit of the government. That was a mandate from Congress. We'd been turned down for statehood only a few years prior because we had failed to understand what would be required of us.

Alaska has never been able to grow a private economy in large part because the land does not really belong to individuals. We will be forever dependent on government handouts until we correct that stupidity. Boom-bust cycles and periods of impoverishment will be our lot until we take back our private property rights.

Comment: Many people that this will affect put in 60-100 hour work weeks, it's not just the doctors. Many of these people had the mind-numbing jobs and decided they wanted more for themselves and their families, so they took the risk of starting their own businesses. The trade-offs for not having a pension plan is the lower corporate tax rates, so you can try and save a similar level that a public employee gets from the government.

To create a pension that pays $40K per year, you need roughly $1Million making 4%. Most public employees can not save that much themselves, yet there are plenty that get more than that in pension money. When you receive the pension, it is counted as income, and marginal tax rates apply, so you might be in the 30% tax bracket.

This is the issue business owners have. If they save that money in their corp as a pension plan, they've paid corp tax first, then a dividend tax later which will equal ~ 34%. Under the new rules, it can total over 60%. That is the problem.

Comment: Climatology and oncology are sciences.

Geology is also a science.

Coal is in decline primarily because it is in geological decline.  Coal peaked in the US in 1999, in terms of BTUs.  There's still a lot left, but growth in coal is not physically possible.  The best coal deposits in the US were in Pennsylvania, where it peaked in 1920.

The arguing over whether coal is good or not (it's not) distracts from the fact that the best coal is long gone, one of the reasons for strip mining and mountaintop removal is the coal companies are going after lower quality coal.

Comment: Sober up and be real careful.
We can't overlook the obligation we owe Tier 1 Public Employees. This is the old pension system that was closed decades ago in July of 1986. Throughout their entire careers deductions were taken from every paycheck to pay for their free medical and monthly stipends upon retirement at age 55.
As Alaskans we owe our retired pensioners this inescapable debt that now totals approximately $15 billion and is a debt that WILL be paid. Federal Law mandates this with State of Alaska's CBR/Perm Fund as collateral.
It's a constitutionally binding debt that Juneau (and all of us) will have to pay with any and all funds, state income taxes, sales taxes and copays from current Tier II (7/1996) and Tier III (7/2006) workers.
The Feds oversee all state pensions with numerous compliance agencies to guarantee there is no bankruptcy, no escape hatch, no defaulting.
This total is more than all of our savings or a quarter of the Permanent Fund's current value.
Stings don't it?

Comment: There's the real universe that we all live in, and there's the fantasy rail universe that is completely separate.  Science is beginning to understand that the fantasy rail universe is not what it seems, and that conversion factors are needed to understand rail numbers in the real universe.  For example, rail costs $5.2 billion in the fantasy rail universe, but in the real universe the cost is $10 billion and rising.  Further, rail creates 10,000 jobs for local people during the construction phase in the fantasy rail universe, but in the real universe it creates only 1,000 jobs.  In the fantasy rail universe, costs are severely underestimated, and benefits are generously overestimated.

Comment: Miller is right; CNN reporter Jim Acosta and immigrant rights advocates are wrong.  The Statue of Liberty had nothing to do with immigration as almost everyone seems to believe.  It was a gift from France to commemorate 100 years of American independence in 1867.  Designed by Frenchman Edouard de Laboulaye, the statue represents Libertas, a Roman goddess, and was named “Liberty Enlightening the World.”  Since de Laboulaye was an abolitionist, the chains at the base of the statue may have had more to do with America freeing slaves than anything else.   To say that the statue is a national symbol for the country’s embrace of immigrants is a rewrite of history.

Comment: After 65 years in Alaska, I never take the beauty for granted. I love sharing the beauty with visitors, which I just spent three weeks doing. Visiting places I've been countless times; I never tire of having my breath taken away with the views both large and small. Even right here in Anchorage, with five mountain ranges around us, the quality of the light in all its mutations throughout the seasons, and the changes in weather fills me with awe daily. Recently standing at the end of Turnagain Arm and thinking of the hundreds of time I had taken in that view, I was moved to tears at the natural beauty that is my home. Sitting at a red light, almost anywhere in Anchorage, I see people looking completely oblivious to their surroundings. All you have to do is look up-look at the mountains, the clouds, the view!  I know all of the places that the roads rise up and give you a far off view of the Alaska Range, the Aleutians, the Talkeetnas; and of course, the ever present Chugach. Never dull.

Comment: On corporate taxes that is true, but the US has THE highest corporate tax rate in the OECD. Comment: Schemes and tricks are best left alone because they are rarely about meeting an individual's needs and objectives.

But that doesn't mean that in the case of mortgages that one can't develop an optimum strategy that meet's their particular needs in terms of both debt repayment and building wealth within an investment portfolio.

Any debt that you incur should have a manageable repayment schedule based upon your income and all your other regular expenditures - including savings.  As income increases it makes sense to allocate that increase to where it will provide the greater benefit.  Paying down a 3% loan faster simply doesn't make sense if you can reasonably expect to earn a higher rate of return on investments.

I recognize that for some people debt simply is comfort issue - owing anything makes them at unease.  However, in the context of this article it would seem that for others the elephant in the room is the inability to pay the loan if rates increase by 1 or 2%.

Comment: Permit me to point out a few things:

1.  Average Canadian commute: 17 km. (Toronto's undoubtedly longer).  Copenhagen: Average cycled per day: Under 2 km.  
2.  The total population of the GTA is about 6.4-million.  Metropolitan Copenhagen's is about 2-million
3.  Area of GTA = 7,000 sq. km. +.  Metropolitan Copenhagen = 3,030 sq. km. 
4.  Toronto's GO Train: 7 lines, 452 km of track, 65 stations.  GO trains per hour: from 6 (during rush-hour) to as few as 1 (at other times).  Plus buses that run on regular highways.  Copenhagen's downtown and outer areas are connected by the S-train: 4 lines, 180 km of track and 84 stations: Six trains (either local or express) per hour on each of the 4 lines all day long, but since all of Copenhagen's S-trains converge in the city-center, there is often no more than 2-3 minutes between trains.
5.  TTC subway:  Four lines, 68 km., 69 stations.  Copenhagen Metro: Two lines (driverless), 29 km., 22 stations.

Comment: I haven't posted in what seems like years, but as one who was formed in a Roman Catholic Seminary and then later ordained an Episcopal priest, I think that the systems are similar enough for comparison.  From start to finish the discernment process is a journey at the parish and diocesan level with the candidate and both lay and ordained people who consult the bishop.  When the candidate is admitted to postulancy they begin formal theological which ends in their ordination.  The Bishop cannot ordain on his/her own whim, it must be with the consent of the ordained and lay members of the Diocese.  The same as to Episcopal Elections. Both lay and ordained must elect the Bishop and then the each Bishop and Diocesan Standing Committee must consent before the person in ordained a bishop. The Presiding Bishop is elected from the House of Bishops.  As with all systems sometimes it works well and other times, not so...but it is a system that trust the Spirit to speak through everyone involved.

Comment: @Cuevas: "leaving the market alone" would require abolishing all of the special treatment that real estate receives (that makes it an attractive investment asset). The Canadian real estate market is already the most interfered-with market in the land (there's nearly a TRILLION dollars in taxpayer guaranteed loans). Just because new measures might work against high prices doesn't mean the character of the market has changed.

Comment: Many years ago, I answered a knock at the door to find two very earnest young Greenpeace fundraisers.  Their chosen approach was to decry the nuclear power plant in Pickering with the claim that nine babies had been born without anuses.  I asked them if that was higher or lower than the national average.  They looked puzzled.  I explained to them that, if the average rate in Pickering was lower than the national average, then perhaps we could claim that nuclear radiation actually reduced the chance of being born without an anus.  "But, but ...", they spluttered, "babies were born without anuses!"  It was an example of Greenpeace's approach to fundraising: raise a topic with no context whatsoever, in the hopes that the resulting uninformed indignation will open the pocketbooks.

If Greenpeace actually accepted that the world requires energy to continue to function, they would embrace nuclear power as the answer to global warming.  But no.  They want all to live a pastoral existence.

Comment: My husband and I started workamping in 2008, it enabled us to travel to Alaska we continued to do so for 5 seasons (and stayed a winter).  We worked in a National Park for 2 seasons and traveled to other locations as well.  The lifestyle is not for everyone and you will not get rich doing it, but if money is the concern these people can stay home and work for the same wages or better.  The trick is not to overextend your budget,  planning helps.  As far as the retirement, a government pension will have raises but a private pension is usually a set amount as the years pass that set amount has less buying power.  You have to save (and the interest rate has to increase so your money earns without risk as in the stock market), you have to been reasonable with your lifestyle. An interesting thing about workamping is the number of younger people doing it now, people in their 30's and 40's and families.  People do it to travel and maybe to find a place to relocate to.

Comment: Nice try and nice con. You sound like the person who produced the pro-Pebble ads.

Kennecott produced 260 pounds of copper for every ton of ore extracted, or a return rate of 13%. Pebble Mine is projected to yield a return of 0.34 of 1%  for a yield of 6.8 pounds per ton. That means that Pebble will have to extract roughly 16 trillion pounds of ore. The neutralizing carbonates used at Kennecott significantly mitigated the risk to the Copper River fish. The geology of the Pebble deposit does not contain significant volumes of neutralizing carbonates. Actually, it contains acidifying elements.

Comment: It hasn’t been a week since the Bank of Canada released its MPR, and its forecasts are already looking suspect. The projection for quarterly real GDP growth in 2017Q3 was revised downwards from 2.0% annualized to 1.8% after the July 2017 update showed no growth in July.  The July revision raised the growth rate very slightly (to 0.02% annualized!) but August showed an unexpected drop. Now the economy would have to grow at a 2.3% annualized rate in September just to meet this modest target. This is possible, but seems unlikely given BC forest fires and cooling housing markets. It could be that the 2.5% growth rate forecast or 2017Q4 was also optimistic.

Comment: Sure it's controversial. Coach Taggart can certainly afford tuition, so if he wanted to maximize the performance of the team, he could pay his son's tuition at UO and save the scholarships for kids who might not play here otherwise. As far as eyebrow-raising is concerned, there's little mystery about what happened to Dougherty. Maybe the possibility of recruiting the son factored into the hiring of his replacement, but only an idiot would hire a coach whose primary qualification was the hope that maybe his kid would play here and maybe the kid would be good. Comment: In terms of price, the GTA average is now $760,356. In April it was $919,589. That’s a drop of more than $159,000, or 17.31% in just a few months. The declines have been historic: down 6.2% in May, another 8.1% in June, and 4.2% in just the first two weeks of July.

By every definition, this is a sharp, deep and ferocious correction. If it were the stock market under discussion, we’d be just days away from an official bear market. That makes talk of a rebound in September kind of comical. Or irresponsible. Any buyer jumping in now to take advantage of a 17% price decline might end up losing all of their equity by the end of the year.

This will not end well...

Comment: Exedus - The real purpose of the Paris agreement is financial, the so- called Green Climate Fund (GCF). While the CGF is not in the Paris agreement, it’s directly related to it.
Its purpose is to transfer wealth from the developed world (us) to the developing one — starting at $100 billion annually by 2020 and rising from there — ostensibly, to help developing nations cope with climate change and develop renewable energy.
The real reason supporters of the Paris agreement are hysterical about Trump’s withdrawal is that it sends a signal to the world that America, under Trump, is not going to play the role of Sugar Daddy for the GCF, by showering it with money from American taxpayers.
Similar to the Paris deal, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s national carbon pricing scheme, and those being implemented by most provincial premiers, aren’t about the environment.
They’re about raiding taxpayers’ wallets in the name of the environment.

Comment: It's true that members of a commission or state agency charged with making a decision in a contested matter are prohibited from privately conducting outside inquiries. Commission members, on the other hand, are supposedly appointed at least in major part because of their knowledge, background and expertise (although you'd be hard pressed to prove that with a couple of the Commission members).  Sheehan is entitled to use her legal expertise, her experience, and the knowledge she's obtained as a Commission member.  She isn't required to forget that Kealoha was forced to resign under a cloud, nor that the federal criminal investigation continues.  Nor should we wish that any Commission member would do so.

Comment: A couple of things. What really got Galileo in trouble was that he had ticked off Pope Urban VIII. Urban had been his friend and patron for many years. However, when Galileo wrote his Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems, one of the characters, Simplicius -- "simpleton" -- quoted Urban. Urban was Not Amused at being called an idiot. Galileo had alienated one of his biggest and most powerful supporters, the Pope, and was called to Rome to explain himself. The official charge against Galileo was heresy, the actual charge was lèse-majesté.

Augustine, in his De Genisi ad Litteram, says that those who preach scientific foolishness in the name of religion are spouting both bad science and bad religion.

Comment: It's worth mentioning, Harold, that the IMF has estimated Canada's subsidy to the petroleum sector  at $34 billion a year. Only the U.S. and Luxembourg are higher. The projected revenues to government from the proposed carbon tax are well below that figure - i.e. we are reducing, not eliminating, the subsidy. It's estimated that if the worldwide subsidy on petroleum was cut, global pollution would be reduced by 13%. And if all, or even most nations agreed to follow suit, no nation would suffer an undue competitive disadvantage. 

Sure it means some adaptation but a carbon tax will not only curb greenhouse gases but enhance the feasibility of green energy initiatives. Canada is as well positioned to take advantage of those opportunities as any other country. An added bonus is that it will increase the competitiveness of local producers and encourage consumers to buy local.

Comment: Or we, as a community, could always look for ways to do a better job of having interesting constructive activities for kids to engage in during the summer months. Do we even have summer school any more? Back in the ice age when I was a child we had some awfully fun classes in the summer.

It's not like it's fifty years ago when almost all households had a stay-at-home parent and the ones that didn't were taken care of by the families of the children's friends.

Comment: Mr. Lowney: How is the laity "co-responsible" for the tens of millions of dollars spent on attorneys fees by the bishops to obfuscate, lie, destroy the reputations of the abused and still not admit the problem continues? How would any one of us be "co-responsible" for the newly ordained priests in many dioceses who love to wear starched surpluses, refuse to permit the laity to even deliver the petitions, and now chase the Girl Scouts from parishes? Wow! I would suggest you spend the next five years lecturing at seminaries preaching the "co-sharing" idea; please send us the results of your research, 'cause if you have answers, I'm more than willing to listen.

Comment: It's like opening a window in Canada for Quebec separatists to win.

The euro-skeptic M5S is riding high, and they promise a referendum on the Euro. If an election is held soon (one possible option), it might win the most votes, and by an ill-considered new law from the Democracy Party, will be given bonus seats to create a parliamentary majority.

If the president appoints a non-partisan interim prime minister, the new PM will not have any mandate to change the election law, and so Italy will end up in uncertainty as long as M5S threatens to win the next election.  If the president appoints an interim PM  from the Democracy Party, and the new PM tries to roll tack the election law, there would be a big outcry about the hypocrisy involved.
